channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Largest Perl team in London with beautiful Docklands offices
item.description: Run by a Perl-loving CTO in beautiful offices with a great view over Canary Wharf, the company manages one legacy Perl codebase and a whole bunch of very new, very shiny, and very modern codebases

item.title: Do some good in the world â€“ Perl developers required for a charity and giving-focused team in Kent, UK
item.description: Join the Kickstarter of the charity world, supporting activists and causes around the world

item.title: Perl for High Performance; Senior Developer, London
item.description: Household name in the UK looking for an excellent problem solver

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: Saturday 3rd November 2018 London

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop
item.description: September 7-8, 2018 Bern.

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop and MojoConf 2018
item.description: September 6-7, 2018, Oslo.

item.title: The Perl Conference in Europe
item.description: August 15-17, 2018, Glasgow. The Call for Papers is open.

item.title: NLPW - Dutch Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: July 7, 2018, Arnhem, The Netherlands

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: The history of CPAN
item.description: While trying to find the date when search.cpan.org was created I bumped into this GitHub repository. Fascinating.

item.title: 2018.25 A Quick One From Salt Lake City
Useless use of private variable in void context
item.description: The Useless use of hash element in void context warning that you might get if you follow my suggestion and turn on warnings in Perl.

item.title: Grant Report: Perl 6: Bugfixing and Performance of Rationals
Web Site Tune-Up: A Case Study
Swat v. 0.2.0
item.description: Simple Web Application Test is a Web testing framework using Outthentic::DSL. This version has some -minor- breaking changes.

item.title: Parsing left recursions
item.description: A lot has been written about parsing left recursion. Unfortunately, much of it simply adds to the mystery. In this post, I hope to frame the subject clearly and briefly.

item.title: Baby Moose
item.description: More Moose

item.title: COED:ETHICS 2018
item.description: A one-day conference on ethics for developers and technologists in London on July 13th. A few Perl-related companies are also among the sponsors.

item.title: Marpa and combinator parsing
item.description: In the post on procedural parsing, the subparsers were like combinators, in that they could be called recursively, so that a parse could be built up from components. Like combinators, each child could return, not just a parse, but a set of parses. And, as in combinators, once a child combinator returned its value, the parent parser could resume parsing at a location specified by the child combinator.

item.title: perldoc.pl - A new way to perldoc
item.description: A new site perldoc.pl to show the documentation of Perl. Very nice! I'd love it to be part of MetaCPAN though as I don't think people (especially beginners) should need to know what is part of Perl and what is an external module.

item.title: Perl 5.28.0 is now available!
item.description: See also the perldelta on MetaCPAN or the perldelta on perldoc.pl.

item.title: StickerYou.com offers a 10% discount to the Perl Weekly community
item.description: As a proud supporter of the Perl community, StickerYou is happy to offer a lifetime 10% discount on all custom stickers, business labels, roll labels, vinyl lettering, custom decals, badges and more. StickerYou.com is your one-stop shop to make your business stick! Use code PERL10 at checkout to apply your discount.

item.title: #361 - Perl 5.28.0 is now available!
item.description:
Hi there!

I hope you'll have a few minutes between two World Cup games to check out some of the articles.

A new version of Perl has been released. Go play with that.

Also today is the date that search.cpan.org will shut down and redirect everything to MetaCPAN.org. Let's thank Graham Barr fnd all the other people who helped him building it and maintaining it for almost 20 years.

Let's also wish good luck to the developers and maintainers of MetaCPAN who will carry now all the traffic. Give them a hand improving and supporting this application!

Enjoy your week!
